image.altText: Jacinta Allan flanked by Vicki Ward and Ben Carroll standing in sunshine outdoors.

props.synopsis: Incoming Victorian premier Jacinta Allan says she will have more to say about a cabinet reshuffle in coming days, after she was elected unopposed by her party room. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: 'Honour and privilege': Jacinta Allan to become Victoria's second female premier

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time. She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks. Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community. "I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said. "Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table." Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Portfolio shake-up on the way

children.content: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time.
She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling
and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks.
Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community.
"I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said.

"Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table."
Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She's flanked by her new deputy Ben Carroll and Member for Eltham Vicki Ward, who is poised to take up Ms Allan's role as Minister for Suburban Rail Loop. "It is such a deep honour and privilege to be in the position to be heading to Government House and to be sworn in as premier of Victoria," Ms Allan said. She paid tribute to the "strong, decisive" premiers that came before her in Steve Bracks, John Brumby and Daniel Andrews and pledged to work hard "each and every day".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Victorian premier Jacinta Allan up now

children.content: She's flanked by her
new deputy Ben Carroll
and
Member for Eltham Vicki Ward
, who is poised to take up Ms Allan's role as Minister for Suburban Rail Loop.

props.alt: Jacinta Allan speaks in a garden.

children.content: Victoria's incoming premier Jacinta Allan (centre) spoke beside deputy Ben Carroll (right).
(ABC News)
"It is such a deep honour and privilege to be in the position to be heading to Government House and to be sworn in as premier of Victoria," Ms Allan said.
She paid tribute to the "strong, decisive" premiers that came before her in Steve Bracks, John Brumby and Daniel Andrews and pledged to work hard "each and every day".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader. She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Watch the press conference live

children.content: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader.
She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.

title.children: Jacinta Allan fends off late challenge to become 49th premier of Victoria

title.children: Qantas grilled by Senate inquiry, as consulting firms KPMG and PwC face more heat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The chair of Qantas has told the senators he should remain as head of the board to maintain continuity at the airline, as the tenability of his position is challenged. "The feedback I got from our major shareholders was they want the continuity of leadership of me as chair of the board, particularly with a new CEO," Mr Goyder told the inquiry. "While I retain the confidence of our shareholders and the board I will continue to serve." More on that here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas chairman stands by his decision to stay

featuredLink.title: Qantas board chair says his future remains tenable, as the airline faces a grilling from senators

children.content: The chair of Qantas has told the senators he should remain as head of the board to maintain continuity at the airline, as the tenability of his position is challenged.
"The feedback I got from our major shareholders was they want the continuity of leadership of me as chair of the board, particularly with a new CEO," Mr Goyder told the inquiry.
"While I retain the confidence of our shareholders and the board I will continue to serve."
More on that here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares fell in broad-based sell off on Wednesday, tracking declines in global equities as fears of higher-for-longer interest rates kept risk sentiment in check, with inflation jumps again in Australia. The ASX 200 fell 0.1 per cent to 7,030. The annual rate of inflation picked up in August, to 5.2 per cent from 4.9 per cent, according to the latest monthly measure of inflation, with this pushed up by more expensive housing, transport, food and insurance. Markets globally continued to digest last week's indication from the US Federal Reserve that it would keep rates higher for longer than investors had previously expected. Back home, gold stocks fell 2 per cent to a more than one-month low as bullion retreated overnight. On the benchmark index, sector majors Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources fell 2 per cent and 2.4 per cent, respectively. Healthcare stocks also retreated 0.7 per cent with biotech major CSL falling 1.4 per cent. Rate-sensitive financial stocks held up well, gaining 0.1 per cent. Technology stocks tracked Wall Street losses to slide nearly 1 per cent, and energy stocks also fell 0.4 per cent. Star Entertainment topped losses on the benchmark index, falling almost 10 per cent to hit its all-time low. The stock resumed trading after completing a discounted $750 million equity raising. The mining sector (-0.1pc) also finished the day in the red. Here are the top and bottom movers of the day.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closed down

children.content: Australian shares fell in broad-based sell off on Wednesday, tracking declines in global equities as fears of higher-for-longer interest rates kept risk sentiment in check, with inflation jumps again in Australia.
The ASX 200 fell 0.1 per cent to 7,030.
The annual rate of
inflation picked up in August
, to 5.2 per cent from 4.9 per cent, according to the latest monthly measure of inflation, with this pushed up by more expensive housing, transport, food and insurance.
Markets globally continued to digest last week's indication from the US Federal Reserve that it would keep rates higher for longer than investors had previously expected.
Back home, gold stocks
fell 2 per cent to a more than one-month low as bullion retreated overnight.
On the benchmark index, sector majors Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources fell 2 per cent and 2.4 per cent, respectively.
Healthcare stocks also retreated 0.7 per cent with biotech major CSL falling 1.4 per cent.
Rate-sensitive financial stocks held up well, gaining 0.1 per cent.
Technology stocks
tracked Wall Street losses to slide nearly 1 per cent, and energy stocks also fell 0.4 per cent.
Star Entertainment
topped losses on the benchmark index, falling almost 10 per cent to hit its all-time low. The stock resumed trading after completing a discounted $750 million equity raising.
The mining sector (-0.1pc) also finished the day in the red.
Here are the top and bottom movers of the day.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Tony Sheldon is asking for "genuine contrition" from Qantas over its many documented problems. Which its chairman Richard Goyder says they do. That's as he faces calls to resign.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas says they have 'genuine contrition'

featuredLink.title: Qantas shareholders demand Richard Goyder quit as chairman as 'more things come to light' about management decisions

children.content: Senator Tony Sheldon is asking for "genuine
contrition" from Qantas over its many documented problems.
Which its chairman Richard Goyder says they do.
That's as he faces calls to resign.
